conclusion: To determine the time at which the two cars collide and whether it occurs before or after 20 seconds of braking, let's analyze the given velocity-time (v-t) graph step by step.

The graph shows the velocity v (in m/s) on the vertical axis and time t (in seconds) on the horizontal axis, with labeled points A and B representing the velocity profiles of Car A and Car B, respectively.
The graph depicts the velocity of the two cars as a function of time after they start braking.
Point A represents the velocity profile of Car A, and Point B represents the velocity profile of Car B.
Both cars start braking simultaneously when they hear the siren, and their velocities decrease over time.
The collision occurs when the cars are at the same position, which depends on their relative velocities and initial positions.
The initial velocity of Car A (Point A) starts higher than that of Car B (Point B) because the line for A is above the line for B at the start.
Both cars decelerate, and their velocity decreases linearly (as indicated by the straight lines).
The lines for A and B intersect at a point, which represents the time when the velocities of the two cars become equal.
A collision occurs when the distance between the two cars becomes zero. The relative position can be found by integrating the relative velocity over time.
The relative velocity is the difference between the velocity of Car A and Car B (v_A - v_B).

The time of collision is when the integral of the relative velocity equals the initial distance between the cars. However, since the initial distance is not provided, we need to infer the collision time from the graph's context and the problem's focus on the 20-second mark.
The lines for Car A and Car B intersect at a point on the graph.

premise: The intersection indicates the time when their velocities are equal.
